quiz.title: Unit 5: Work & Energy (Quiz 1)
quiz.subtitle: Fundamentals of Work and Energy (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Work, Kinetic Energy, and Potential Energy

questions.question: Which of the following quantities is a scalar?
questions.explanation: Work has magnitude only and no direction, hence it is a scalar quantity.

questions.question: When a force acts on a body and there is no displacement, the work done is:
questions.explanation: Work is given by W = F × d × cosθ. If displacement d = 0, then W = 0.

questions.question: A force of 20 N moves an object 5 m in the direction of the force. Work done is:
The SI unit of energy is:
questions.explanation: The Joule (J) is the SI unit for both work and energy.

questions.question: A boy lifts a 10 kg box vertically through 2 m. The work done is approximately:
When work is done on a system, energy of the system:
questions.explanation: Positive work adds energy to the system, increasing its energy.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a form of mechanical energy?
questions.explanation: Heat energy is a form of thermal, not mechanical, energy.

questions.question: A 5 kg object moving at 4 m/s has kinetic energy:
Doubling the speed of an object increases its kinetic energy by:
questions.explanation: KE ∝ v², so doubling v makes KE four times larger.

questions.question: The potential energy of a 2 kg body at a height of 10 m is:
Which of the following statements about work and energy is correct?
options: Work is the rate of energy change
Work and energy have the same unit
Energy is always greater than work
questions.explanation: Both work and energy are measured in Joules.

questions.question: If the angle between force and displacement is 90°, the work done is:
questions.explanation: W = Fd cosθ; when θ = 90°, cos90° = 0 → W = 0.

questions.question: Which of these has maximum potential energy?
options: A book on a high shelf
questions.explanation: A book on a high shelf has gravitational potential energy due to its elevated position.

questions.question: If power is the rate of doing work, then its SI unit is:
questions.explanation: 1 Watt = 1 Joule per second.

questions.question: A machine does 600 J of work in 20 s. Power developed is:
A man carries a 15 kg load 20 m horizontally at constant speed. Work done against gravity is:
questions.explanation: No vertical displacement means no work against gravity.

questions.question: The work done by friction on a moving body is usually:
questions.explanation: Friction opposes motion; hence work done by it is negative.

questions.question: The energy possessed by a stretched rubber band is:
questions.explanation: It stores energy due to change in shape — elastic potential energy.

questions.question: Work done against friction is converted into:
questions.explanation: Work against friction produces heat due to surface resistance.

questions.question: A 60 W bulb consumes 60 J of energy in:
questions.explanation: Power = Energy / time → time = 60/60 = 1 s.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a strong grasp of work and energy fundamentals.
scoreMessages.70: Good job! You understand the core concepts but should review work calculations with angles.
scoreMessages.50: A fair effort. Focus on the definitions of work, energy, and power, and practice basic calculations.
scoreMessages.0: Keep trying! Review the basic concepts of work as force times displacement and the different forms of energy.
